declarations.comments:
Convenience synonym for defining the type of updaters within a Panda
application.
declarations.title: Updater

declarations.comments:
Properties are either static key/value pairs, listeners for DOM updates
(that can then change the properties on an element), or producers of
events (that then bubble up to the `update` function).
declarations.title: Property

declarations.comments: The effects that are used within Panda.
declarations.title: FX

declarations.comments:
A component is either a delegate (embedded sub-application), element
(with properties and children and an HTML representation), or just some
text.
declarations.title: Component

declarations.comments:
A Panda application is a view (written in the component DSL) that is
interpreted into an element (to be attached to the DOM), an event stream
(that is merged with the subscription) that feeds into the update
function, that update function (which produces updates for the view), and
intiial state and update.
declarations.title: Application

declarations.comments:
Run a Panda application. This takes a Panda application and appends it to
the `document.body`, effectively commandeering the entire page. If this
_isn't_ what you want, chances are that you're after `runApplicationIn`,
which will allow you to embed a Panda application inside the DOM. Note
that this function returns a `Maybe`, depending on the presence of `body`,
so this result should be checked to determine whether instantiation was
successful.
declarations.title: runApplication

declarations.comments:
Given an application, produce the DOM element and the system of events
around it. This is mutually recursive with the `render` function.
declarations.title: bootstrap

declarations.comments: Given a component, render the DOM node, and set up the event system.
declarations.title: render

declarations.comments:
Render a Property on a DOM element. This also initialises any `Watcher`
components, and sets up their event handlers and cancellers.
declarations.title: render

declarations.comments: An element with no specified properties and fixed children.
declarations.title: StaticElementWithoutProperties

declarations.comments: An element whose immediate children definitely don't respond to updates.
declarations.title: StaticElement

declarations.comments: A non-container element that has no custom properties.
declarations.title: SelfClosingElementWithoutProperties

declarations.comments: An element that, according to the HTML spec, is not a container.
declarations.title: SelfClosingElement

declarations.comments: An element with no specified properties.
declarations.title: ElementWithoutProperties

declarations.comments: A regular element.
declarations.title: Element

declarations.comments:
Given an update and state, maybe produce a value. If a value _is_
produced, use this value to render a component. As with the other render
methods, this will trigger a full re-render.
declarations.title: renderMaybe

declarations.comments:
Regardless of the update, re-render with no interest in what the update
was. Again, this will be a real performance-killer in larger applications,
so use it with caution. Beyond very simple cases, it's usually a sign that
something needs rethinking.
declarations.title: renderAlways'

declarations.comments:
Regardless of the update, re-render this child. **NB** that this is
probably a bad idea within a larger application, as it will probably
equate to a lot of unnecessary re-render. Consider embedding such an
element within a delegate and filtering updates to improve performance.
declarations.title: renderAlways

declarations.comments:
Wrap an application within a component such that it can be embedded within
a larger application.
declarations.title: delegate

declarations.comments: A regular element.
declarations.title: Element

declarations.comments: An element whose immediate children definitely don't respond to updates.
declarations.title: StaticElement

declarations.comments: An element that, according to the HTML spec, is not a container.
declarations.title: SelfClosingElement

declarations.comments: A non-container element that has no custom properties.
declarations.title: SelfClosingElementWithoutProperties

declarations.comments: An element with no specified properties.
declarations.title: ElementWithoutProperties

declarations.comments: An element with no specified properties and fixed children.
declarations.title: StaticElementWithoutProperties

declarations.comments:
Regardless of the update, re-render this child. **NB** that this is
probably a bad idea within a larger application, as it will probably
equate to a lot of unnecessary re-render. Consider embedding such an
element within a delegate and filtering updates to improve performance.
declarations.title: renderAlways

declarations.comments:
Regardless of the update, re-render with no interest in what the update
was. Again, this will be a real performance-killer in larger applications,
so use it with caution. Beyond very simple cases, it's usually a sign that
something needs rethinking.
declarations.title: renderAlways'

declarations.comments:
Given an update and state, maybe produce a value. If a value _is_
produced, use this value to render a component. As with the other render
methods, this will trigger a full re-render.
declarations.title: renderMaybe

declarations.comments:
An algebra for array updates. We use this to describe the ways in which we
would like to update the DOM.
declarations.title: ArrayUpdate

declarations.comments:
Components are updated using the array algebra, but specialised to
component values.
declarations.title: ComponentUpdate

declarations.comments: An algebra for map updates.
declarations.title: MapUpdate

declarations.comments: Properties are updated using the map algebra specialised to strings.
declarations.title: PropertyUpdate

declarations.comments: The effects that are used within Panda.
declarations.title: FX

declarations.comments: All the possible event producers.
declarations.title: Producer

declarations.comments:
Properties are either static key/value pairs, listeners for DOM updates
(that can then change the properties on an element), or producers of
events (that then bubble up to the `update` function).
declarations.title: Property

declarations.comments:
Children on elements can either be static (not looking for events), or
dynamic. Note that the children of static children can be dynamic!
declarations.title: Children

declarations.comments:
A component is either a delegate (embedded sub-application), element
(with properties and children and an HTML representation), or just some
text.
declarations.title: Component

declarations.comments:
Component delegates allow us to reuse applications within larger
applications, provided that we can wire up the two event systems. Note
the possible leak here: in certain cases, we _can_ isolate a
sub-application as a black box within a larger application by ignoring all
incoming updates and outgoing events.
declarations.title: ComponentDelegate

declarations.comments:
In practice, we don't really care what the types are within a
sub-application, as long as we have an appropriate mapping to and from the
parent types. So, we can existentialise these inner types.
declarations.title: ComponentDelegateX

declarations.comments: Make an existential component delegate.
declarations.title: mkComponentDelegateX

declarations.comments:
Retrieve a component delegate from an existentialised delegate, using the
functions within `focus` to wire up the two applications.
declarations.title: runComponentDelegateX

declarations.comments:
An event system defines the update/event mechanism for a particular
component. When we update the DOM, we must remember to cancel outgoing
elements, and register new update handlers.
declarations.title: EventSystem

declarations.comments:
Convenience synonym for defining the type of updaters within a Panda
application.
declarations.title: Updater

declarations.comments:
A Panda application is a view (written in the component DSL) that is
interpreted into an element (to be attached to the DOM), an event stream
(that is merged with the subscription) that feeds into the update
function, that update function (which produces updates for the view), and
intiial state and update.
declarations.title: Application

declarations.comments: Update a property whenever a predicate is satisfied.
declarations.title: watchWhen

declarations.comments: Given a set of predicate/render pairs, update the property accordingly
declarations.title: watchSet

declarations.comments: Watch for a particular update.
declarations.title: watchFor

declarations.comments:
Run a property update regardless of the update that is detected. For
larger applications, this will happen very regularly, so be careful with
this...
declarations.title: watchAny

declarations.comments:
General constructor for property watches. Kind of the "advanced mode" -
use the other functions if possible.
declarations.title: watch

declarations.comments: Event producers
declarations.title: Producer

declarations.comments:
Static properties are those whose `update state event` triple can be
anything.
declarations.title: StaticProperty

declarations.comments: Event conversions
declarations.title: eventToDragEvent

declarations.comments: Specifically build a producer of a given input type.
declarations.title: makeProducer

declarations.comments: Make a producer with the given handler.
declarations.title: makeProducer'

declarations.comments: Get the value of the target DOM element.
declarations.title: targetValue

declarations.comments:
General constructor for property watches. Kind of the "advanced mode" -
use the other functions if possible.
declarations.title: watch

declarations.comments:
Run a property update regardless of the update that is detected. For
larger applications, this will happen very regularly, so be careful with
this...
declarations.title: watchAny

declarations.comments: Watch for a particular update.
declarations.title: watchFor

declarations.comments: Given a set of predicate/render pairs, update the property accordingly
declarations.title: watchSet

declarations.comments: Update a property whenever a predicate is satisfied.
declarations.title: watchWhen
